Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the spread and danger of the "flesh-eating STD" donovanosis by using sensationalized language and scary-sounding headlines.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the assertion that donovanosis is spreading or making a comeback.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the single case of donovanosis in England represents a resurgence or increase in prevalence of the disease, without providing any context or comparison to previous data.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not consider alternative explanations for the presence of donovanosis, such as the possibility that it is still a very rare disease with isolated cases.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that donovanosis ulcers will not spread and damage healthy tissue unless they are left untreated, therefore exaggerating the "flesh-eating" aspect of the disease.
Understate: The claim understates the rarity of donovanosis by presenting it as a widespread or increasing problem, when in fact it is a very rare disease with only one recently-documented case in the UK.
Falters at times: The claim falters in providing accurate and reliable information about the nature and spread of donovanosis, as it relies on sensationalized headlines and lacks supporting evidence.
